headline: Comprehensive logic
text: Peter Lampl says independent schools should "open their doors to all young people based on ability rather than ability to pay" (Letters, 15 June). But why should a child with a particular set of narrowly defined abilities at age 11 be given more opportunities than another? Lampl says "[given] a clean slate, a truly comprehensive school system would be my starting point". So why not follow this logic and require schools in receipt of charitable status or state funding to admit a comprehensive intake? Many state schools already have a banding test to ensure that they have a good mix of all abilities, a system which does not disadvantage those who cannot afford expensive coaching. Jane SandersonLondon   Lampl wants pupil admissions based on ability. In other words, he wants grammar schools. What does he think should happen to the dimwits he does not want polluting these elite establishments?Tim GosslingCambridge
